year. Anderson County Schools is an Exemplary District in Achievement and an Advancing District Overall, which combines both achievement and growth. ACS had 7 Reward Schools, 5 Level 5 schools, and 6 Level 4 schools. ","pause":"","link":"","target":"_self"}]}}

a.aria-label: Latest Update: (April 17th) Anderson County Schools Image

p.span:
After Tennessee Governor Bill Lees announcement on April 15th, Anderson County Schools has decided to close our school buildings for the remainder of this school year. In addition to the governors recommendation of closing school buildings for the remainder of this school year, he issued a safer at home order to the residents of Tennessee lasting through April 30th. With this guidance Anderson County Schools has decided to continue our online and packet education plan through May 8th. Students will continue exactly what they have been doing through May 8th. After May 8th, teacher and support staff will be available to help any student who needs help or remediation through the end of the school year.
Education in Anderson County is not just about a grade, it is about the continued learning and the success of every student, every day. We are continuing to provide students with the education, knowledge, and the materials to go to the next level, either in the classroom or in their future career.
More information about grades will be sent out as we receive more guidance from the state.
The administrators of Anderson County Schools have cancelled all awards days, social events, end of year celebrations, dances (including both High School proms) and all other school sponsored events. Anderson County administrators are currently working on plans for graduations for both Anderson County High School and Clinton High School. Details or dates have not been finalized but information regarding how and if these events will take place will be released soon.
If you or your family is in need of food please contact the principal of the school your student attends to receive assistance. Email addresses of our principals can be found at www.ACS.ac on the schools website.

a.title: Go to comments for Latest Update: (April 17th) Anderson County Schools

p.span:
10:30 am until 12:30 pm on Mondays and Thursdays Anderson County School Nutrition will provide 3 days of Breakfast and Lunch to anyone under 19 years of age beginning weekly on Monday, March 30 at 5 sites. Grab-and-Go food will be available outside the school in prepackaged form. Each child receiving meals must be in vehicle or child must pick up meals if walking from their home.
Follow signage directions at the following locations and look for the car line or canopy awning:
Andersonville Elementary School-1951 Mountain Road, Andersonville
Claxton Elementary-2218 Clinton Highway, Powell
Clinton Middle School-110 North Hicks Street, Clinton (Pick-up line is on the back of the school on Marshall St.)
Grand Oaks Elementary-1033 Oliver Springs Highway, Clinton
Lake City Elementary, 402 Lindsay Street, Lake City
Hours, days, and locations are subject to change. Please visit acs.ac or ACS Facebook pages for continued updates.

a.title: Go to comments for Meal Distribution Information

a.aria-label: Tennessee Department of Education Update on Coronavirus (Click Here For More Information) Image

img.alt: Tennessee Department of Education Update on Coronavirus (Click Here For More Information)

a.span: Tennessee Department of Education Update on Coronavirus (Click Here For More Information)

p.span:
Tennessee Department of Health has launched a Tennessee Coronavirus Public Information Line in partnership with the Tennessee Poison Center. The hotline number is 877-857-2945 and will be available from 10 a.m. to 10 p.m. CT daily.
COVID-19 coronavirus is a respiratory illness caused by a novel (new) virus. Stopping transmission (spread) of the virus through everyday practices is the best way to keep people healthy.
State health officials are currently taking steps to prevent the spread of COVID-19 in Tennessee. Schools can play a key role in this effort. Through collaboration and coordination with local health departments, schools can take steps to disseminate information about the disease and its potential transmission within their school community.
Tennessee Department of Health has launched a Tennessee Coronavirus Public Information Line in partnership with the Tennessee Poison Center. The hotline number is 877-857-2945 and will be available from 10 a.m. to 10 p.m. CT daily.
